items.title: Obituary: VERNON HAROLD COE
items.description: May 17, 1936 – February 14, 2026 Vernon Harold Coe, age 89, of Sturgis, SD passed away Saturday February 14, 2026, at his residence. He was born May 17, 1936, in Hettinger, ND, son of...
items.summary:
Vernon Harold Coe, a 89-year-old resident of Sturgis, South Dakota, passed away on February 14, 2026. He was born on May 17, 1936, in Hettinger, North Dakota, to Harold Coe and Mrytle Culver.

Key details:
- Vernon attended grade school in Harding County, riding horseback to school from 4th through 8th grade. He then attended one year of high school in Belle Fourche, South Dakota, and finished his education at the South Dakota State School of Agriculture in Brookings in 1954.
- Vernon's hobbies included breaking and selling horses, as well as participating in saddle bronc and bareback riding at local rodeos.
- In 1960, he married Janet Witcher in Belle Fourche, and they had three children: Jody Pekas of Rapid City, Kim (Patti) Coe of Vale, and Ken (Melissa) Coe of Georgia. Vernon and Janet later divorced.
- Vernon enjoyed a life of ranching in various locations near Bison, South Dakota, and later near Sturgis. He also worked as a truck driver from 1977 until his retirement in 2009.
- Vernon is survived by his three children, nine grandchildren, and ten great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his parents, two sisters, one grandchild, two great-grandchildren, a nephew, a son-in-law, and other relatives.
- Services will be held on Friday, February 20, at 12:00 noon at Kinkade's Funeral Home in Sturgis, followed by a burial at the Black Hills National Cemetery and a luncheon at the Vets Club in Sturgis.

items.title: Schuler Red Angus honored for commitment to community and education
items.description: Input, leadership, and education were all words used to describe the collaborative efforts of Schuler Red Angus when owners Butch and David Schuler received the 2025 Outstanding Service to Agriculture Award from the University of...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Schuler Red Angus, owned by Butch and David Schuler, received the 2025 Outstanding Service to Agriculture Award from the University of Nebraska Panhandle Research, Extension and Education Center (PREEC).

- The award recognized Schuler Red Angus' contributions in leadership, service, and dedication to agriculture in the Panhandle region, as well as their meaningful impact on the broader community.

- Some of Schuler Red Angus' contributions include:
  - Hosting wildfire recovery meetings following the Hackberry fire in 2021.
  - Hosting cheatgrass management education opportunities highlighting new herbicides.
  - Hosting multiple UNL student groups to help them better understand ranching in western Nebraska.
  - Providing valuable input and leadership on facilitating relevant research and extension programming at PREEC.
  - Hosting a cattle management tour group from Argentina in 2025.
  - Butch Schuler's involvement in the PREEC advisory committee.

- Dr. John Westra, PREEC Director, presented the award to Butch and David Schuler at the annual Beef Feedlot Roundtables on February 17, 2026, in Bridgeport, Nebraska.

- The Schulers expressed their appreciation for the university's partnership and their pride in being able to give back to the agricultural community.

items.title: Inaugural professorship awarded to Dr. Bijesh Marharjan
items.description: Dr. Bijesh Maharjan, associate professor in agronomy and horticulture and extension specialist at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) Panhandle Research, Extension, and Education Center (PREEC) in Scottsbluff, has been named the Ray and Jolene Ward...
items.summary:
Bijesh Maharjan, an associate professor and extension specialist at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) Panhandle Research, Extension, and Education Center, has been named the inaugural Ray and Jolene Ward Professor of Soil Health Science. This new professorship, effective April 1, 2026, honors the Wards for their longstanding contributions to Nebraska agriculture through their company, Ward Laboratories, Inc.

Ray Ward founded Ward Laboratories in 1983 and has been a tireless advocate for sustainable soil management practices that enhance soil health, conserve resources, and improve long-term productivity. He has received numerous honors, including from the Soil Science Society of America, Nebraska Farm Bureau, and Nebraska Hall of Agricultural Achievement.

As the first recipient of the professorship, Dr. Maharjan has focused his work on soil health, proposing the concepts of the "Soil Health Gap" and the "Soil Health Cycle." The Soil Health Gap framework allows for comparing cropland soil health to a native reference site, while the Soil Health Cycle integrates human dimensions, management practices, soil health indicators, and ecosystem service outcomes.

Dr. Maharjan's extension efforts have led to the establishment of the Nebraska Soil Health School, which brings together NRCS experts, university scientists, and producer-leaders for hands-on events across the state. Participants have consistently praised the quality of the learning opportunities, which combine demonstrations and evidence-based discussions.

items.title: President Trump Signs U.S.-Indonesia Trade Deal Expanding Access for U.S. Beef
items.description: WASHINGTON (February 20, 2026) ‚Äì Today, the National Cattlemen’s Beef Association (NCBA) welcomed the announcement that U.S. beef exports will now have duty-free access to Indonesia. Gaining access to the Indonesian market, where U.S. beef...
items.summary:
Key points:

- President Trump signed a U.S.-Indonesia trade deal that expands access for U.S. beef exports to Indonesia.

- Under the deal, Indonesia will purchase at least 50,000 metric tons of U.S. beef annually. 

- Indonesia now recognizes USDA authority on food safety and animal health, opening more opportunities for U.S. beef exports.

- This deal, combined with the Taiwan trade deal signed last week, gives U.S. cattle producers more market access than they have had in decades.

- The National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) welcomed the announcement, as gaining access to the Indonesian market has been a priority for years due to significant tariff and non-tariff trade barriers.

- NCBA President Gene Copenhaver stated this agreement provides more opportunities for producer profitability, as Indonesia is the fourth most populous country and the largest halal beef market in the world.

- NCBA thanked President Trump and U.S. Trade Representative Ambassador Jamieson Greer for their work in securing this trade deal to benefit American producers.

items.title: Montana Farm Bureau Leaders Advocate for Ag Interests in Washington
items.description: Washington‚ÄîMontana Farm Bureau members traveled to Washington, D.C., February 10‚Äì12, 2026, to participate in the American Farm Bureau Issues Advisory Committee meetings. These selected members are appointed to specific committees to discuss pressing agricultural concerns...
items.summary:
C. from February 10-12, 2026 to advocate for agricultural interests. The delegation, led by MFBF Senior Director of Governmental Affairs Nicole Rolf, participated in advisory committee meetings, congressional visits, and meetings with agency officials.

Some key points from the article:

- Jess Bandel, a wheat farmer, said the cattle market outlook remains strong due to high consumer demand, but lingering concerns over tariffs, low commodity prices, and fertilizer costs continue to impact the grain market.

- Greg Gabel, a sugar beet farmer, discussed how the agriculture industry can utilize artificial intelligence and robotics to address future labor shortages, as well as concerns about the presence of tech company data centers in rural areas.

- Rich Franko, a rancher, said a major discussion focused on the issue of vacant allotments affecting Western states and the positive impact of filling those permits on the cattle industry.

- The group also discussed emerging issues like cryptocurrency regulation and the desire to apply the same principles of transparency and market fairness used in agriculture to the cryptocurrency market as it evolves.

Overall, the Montana Farm Bureau leaders advocated for agricultural interests and discussed key policy issues impacting farmers and ranchers during their time in Washington.

items.title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Majority of Trump‚Äôs Tariffs
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî On Friday, the Supreme Court ruled President Donald Trump overstepped his authority in imposing tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). “…we hold that IEEPA does not authorize the president to impose tariffs,” wrote Chief Justice John Roberts. The ruling invalidated the majority of tariffs the President has implemented since he […] The post Supreme Court Strikes Down Majority of Trump‚Äôs Tariffs appeared first on Morning Ag Clips
items.summary:
The ruling invalidated the majority of tariffs the President has implemented since taking office in 2025. 

Several major agricultural organizations have responded to the Supreme Court's decision:
- The American Farm Bureau Federation (AFBF) President Zippy Duvall said the tariffs created hardships for farmers, and urged the administration to find other ways to resolve trade disputes. He asked the President to avoid imposing any new tariffs on agricultural inputs.
- The National Farmers Union (NFU) President Rob Larew said the tariffs raised input costs, disrupted exports, and hurt family farmers. He called on the administration not to pursue similar tariffs under other authorities.
- The American Soybean Association (ASA) President Scott Metzger said soybean farmers have faced rising input costs from the tariffs. He urged the President to refrain from imposing tariffs on agricultural inputs going forward.
- The National Corn Growers Association (NCGA) said it supports efforts to maintain and increase market access, and urged the administration to implement and finalize ongoing trade deals.
- The American Seed Trade Association (ASTA) said tariffs have created uncertainty and significantly increased costs for U.S. seed companies, and called for eliminating tariffs on planting seeds.

The article was published on February 20, 2026. It does not contain any other specific dates, deadlines, prices, or statistics.

items.title: MFGA to Host Winter Educational Program for Growers on February 24
items.description: BOYLSTON, Mass. ‚Äî The Massachusetts Flower Growers Association (MFGA) will host its annual Winter Educational Program on Tuesday, February 24, 2026, at the New England Botanical Garden at Tower Hill in Boylston, Massachusetts. Designed for greenhouse growers, outdoor cut flower growers, and garden retailers, the full-day program will provide timely education, practical resources, and networking […] The post MFGA to Host Winter Educational Program for Growers on February 24 appeared first o
items.summary:
The Massachusetts Flower Growers Association (MFGA) will host its annual Winter Educational Program on Tuesday, February 24, 2026, at the New England Botanical Garden at Tower Hill in Boylston, Massachusetts. The full-day program is designed for greenhouse growers, outdoor cut flower growers, and garden retailers, and will provide timely education, practical resources, and networking opportunities to help growers prepare for the 2026 season.

The program will feature expert presentations on key topics, including:

- Energy incentive programs - Griffin Pelaia, Agricultural and Energy Engineer with UMass Extension, will provide an overview of state and federal funding opportunities available to support on-farm energy projects, focusing on NRCS cost-share programs and other clean energy incentives.

- Biocontrol advancements - Phil Gerry, Technical Sales Consultant with Koppert USA, will share the latest developments in biocontrol for greenhouse crops, including new products, formulations, and distribution methods.

- Plant variety selection - Kerri Stafford, Head Grower and Annual Production Manager at Cavicchio Greenhouses, will present a review of the best new plant varieties for 2026.

- Marketing strategies - Nicky Bartley, owner of Cross Street Flower Farm in Norwell, Massachusetts, will share her experience building a successful outdoor cut flower business, including effective production and marketing strategies.

The program has been approved for two pesticide recertification credits. The Winter Educational Program is open to both MFGA members and non-members, and lunch is included with full-day registration.

items.title: USDA opens RFI on data products
items.description: Agency seeks producer input on how to improve accuracy, usefulness, transparency and ease of access across its data outputs.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a Request for Information (RFI) to gather producer input on improving the accuracy, usefulness, transparency, and accessibility of its data products. The RFI is focused on the agency's data outputs across various agricultural sectors. Producers are encouraged to provide feedback on how the USDA can enhance the quality and usability of its data to better serve the needs of farmers and the agricultural industry. The RFI is open for public comments until June 20, 2023. Feedback received will be used by the USDA to identify ways to improve the delivery and presentation of its data, ensuring it is more readily available and beneficial to producers.

items.title: Cattle futures lower to finish the week
items.description: At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live and feeder cattle were lower waiting on direct business to develop and Friday‚Äôs On Feed report from the USDA.  April live cattle closed $1.42 lower at $242 and June live cattle closed $1.35 lower at $237.52.  March feeder cattle closed $2.25 lower at $368.02 and April feeder cattle closed […] The post Cattle futures lower to finish the week appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Cattle futures closed lower this week on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange:

- April live cattle closed $1.42 lower at $242 per cwt
- June live cattle closed $1.35 lower at $237.52 per cwt 
- March feeder cattle closed $2.25 lower at $368.02 per cwt
- April feeder cattle also closed lower

The decline was due to market participants waiting on the release of the USDA's monthly Cattle on Feed report, which was published on Friday. Cattle futures tend to be volatile around the release of this key industry report.

items.title: January milk production rises as USDA reports four percent of dairies closed
items.description: An ag economist says milk production is likely to increase in 2026 while cow numbers tighten.  During the USDA Ag Outlook, Anthony Fisher highlighted how high beef prices have been impacting milking herd dynamics. ‚ÄúIt’s expected to decline from the recent highs as producers respond to lower milk prices, higher replacement heifer costs, and an […] The post January milk production rises as USDA reports four percent of dairies closed appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: In January 2023, U.S. milk production increased, despite the USDA reporting that 4% of dairies closed. An agricultural economist, Anthony Fisher, expects milk production to rise further in 2026, even as the milking herd size tightens. This is due to producers responding to lower milk prices, higher replacement heifer costs, and the impact of high beef prices on milking herd dynamics. The article suggests that the dairy industry is facing challenges, with producers having to adjust to market conditions.

items.title: Wheat ends week on higher note, helped out by drought concerns, short covering
items.description: Soybeans were lower on profit taking and technical selling, while still ending the week with modest gains. Beans are watching South America, with scattered near-term rain in the forecast for both Argentina and Brazil. Export sales were up on the week, but lower than average at 29.3 million bushels, led by China and Egypt. The […] The post Wheat ends week on higher note, helped out by drought concerns, short covering appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Wheat prices ended the week higher, supported by concerns about drought conditions and short-covering by traders. Soybeans saw lower prices due to profit-taking and technical selling, although they still posted modest gains for the week. Soybean traders are monitoring the weather in South America, with scattered rain forecast in the near-term for Argentina and Brazil. Weekly soybean export sales were 29.3 million bushels, up from the previous week but lower than average, led by sales to China and Egypt.

items.title: Bovine TB detected in Michigan dairy herd
items.description: The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development says a dairy herd in northern Michigan has been confirmed with bovine tuberculosis. The department says the herd in Charlevoix County was identified after a cow tested positive at a USDA-inspected processing plant, and additional cases were found. Two cases of the disease were reported in livestock herds […] The post Bovine TB detected in Michigan dairy herd appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: A dairy herd in Charlevoix County, Michigan has been confirmed with bovine tuberculosis (TB). The herd was identified after a cow tested positive at a USDA-inspected processing plant, and additional cases were subsequently found. Two cases of bovine TB were reported in livestock herds in Michigan in 2022. The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development is working with the herd owner to contain the outbreak and prevent the spread of the disease to other herds.

items.title: U.S. pork thrives in 2025, beef sees gains despite China losses
items.description: For both U.S. beef and pork, December was an especially strong month for variety meat exports.
items.summary: In 2025, U.S. pork exports saw significant growth, reaching a record 3.15 million metric tons, up 10.5% from 2024. Beef exports also increased, reaching 1.5 million metric tons, up 8.5% year-over-year, despite losing 25% of China's market share. The strong export performance was driven by robust global demand and competitive U.S. prices. USMEF reported that December 2025 was an exceptionally strong month for U.S. beef and pork variety meat exports. Industry experts expect continued growth in 2026, with pork exports projected to reach 3.3 million metric tons and beef exports 1.55 million metric tons.

items.title: Supreme Court strikes down Trump‚Äôs tariffs
items.description: Justices say in their majority ruling IEEPA does not give the President authority to impose tariffs.
items.summary: The Supreme Court struck down the Trump administration's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, ruling that the president exceeded his authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The 5-4 decision concluded that IEEPA does not grant the president unilateral power to impose tariffs for national security reasons. This overturns the 25% tariff on steel and 10% tariff on aluminum that President Trump implemented in 2018, affecting key US agricultural trade partners like Canada, Mexico, and the EU. The tariffs had raised costs for US farmers and ranchers, who faced retaliatory tariffs on their exports. The ruling is a victory for the agricultural industry, which had argued the tariffs hurt their businesses. It remains to be seen how the Biden administration will respond to the court's decision limiting the president's trade powers.

items.title: Markets juggled tariff news, economic data and USDA outlook
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Traders needed plenty of antacids today.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's latest World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates (WASDE) report projected 2022-23 corn production at 13.8 billion bushels, up 4% from the previous year, with yields forecast at 177 bushels per acre. Soybean production is expected to reach 4.5 billion bushels, up 2% from 2021-22, with yields projected at 51.5 bushels per acre.

The USDA also forecast 2022-23 wheat production at 1.8 billion bushels, down 8% from 2021-22, with yields forecast at 49.5 bushels per acre. This reflects ongoing drought conditions in parts of the U.S.

The report also showed higher estimates for global grain and oilseed supplies compared to the previous month, with corn and soybean ending stocks rising. However, wheat ending stocks were lowered due to reduced production forecasts.

Commodity prices were volatile throughout the day, with soybeans and corn futures declining while wheat futures rose. Soybean futures fell $0.39 per bushel, corn fell $0.12 per bushel, and wheat rose $0.30 per bushel.

The market also reacted to news of potential new tariffs on Chinese goods, adding to ongoing uncertainty. Farmers should monitor these developments and adjust plans as needed.

items.title: You vs. You: The hazards of ‚Äòresulting‚Äô
items.description: The results of our decision-making aren‚Äôt always a good indicator of the reliability of our process.
items.summary:
This can be particularly problematic in agriculture, where outcomes are heavily influenced by uncontrollable factors like weather.

The article cites a study that found farmers who experienced high yields one year were more likely to use the same decision-making process the following year, even if the weather conditions were vastly different. This 'resulting' behavior can lead to poor decisions and suboptimal outcomes.

The article recommends that farmers focus on improving their decision-making process rather than solely chasing positive results. This may involve gathering more data, seeking expert advice, and regularly reviewing and refining their approach. 

Quoting University of Illinois professor David Downey, the article states that "good decision-making is a skill that can be developed" and encourages farmers to be "more disciplined about how [they] make decisions".

The article emphasizes that outcomes are not always a reliable indicator of decision quality, and that farmers should strive to make well-reasoned choices based on the information available, rather than being swayed by short-term results.

items.title: Winter Diagnostics Revolution: Remote Monitoring Systems That Keep Farm and Construction Equipment Primed for Spring
items.description: BALTIMORE, Md. ‚Äî Snow-covered fields may seem peaceful, but the spring planting season’s pressures are already building. Equipment sitting idle through freezing temperatures, moisture and fluctuating conditions can develop hidden issues long before rows get ploughed. When narrow planting windows open, every hour counts. You can now track machinery health year-round with remote monitoring systems, […] The post Winter Diagnostics Revolution: Remote Monitoring Systems That Keep Farm and
items.summary:
These systems use Internet of Things sensors, telematics modules, and cloud-based software to track machine health year-round, transforming the idle winter months into a time of active preparation.

Key points:
- Unplanned equipment failures or emergency maintenance can cost farmers an average of $3,348 per season.
- Remote monitoring systems provide early fault detection, allow for parts ordering in the off-season, and enable scheduled service windows during slower months.
- Global industries can save 30-50% on downtime and reduce maintenance costs by 10-40% using advanced telematics.
- Remote systems confirm engine readiness, produce error logs, and identify minor issues early to improve equipment longevity and resale value.
- Experts recommend piloting remote monitoring on high-value assets, reviewing data monthly, and integrating alerts into routine planning.
- Working with dealers and original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) can provide factory-installed or retrofit remote diagnostic options.

The article emphasizes that with remote monitoring in place, winter becomes part of the maintenance strategy, reducing surprises and supporting a smooth transition from storage to service when the growing season begins.

items.title: Best Pitch Deck Design Agencies for Agriculture Startups in 2026

Investors are pouring billions into startups that promise to reshape how the world grows food, manages farms, and builds sustainable supply chains. But here is the problem – most agtech founders are brilliant at soil science, drone logistics, or […] The post Best Pitch Deck Design Agencies for Agriculture Startups in 2026 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.

It addresses the challenges agtech founders face in translating complex science and technology into a narrative that resonates with investors.

Key points:

- The right pitch deck design partner can help distill technical innovations into a clear investor story, design effective data visualizations, and ensure brand consistency across all materials.
