items.title: Texas A&M animal science faculty and graduate student earn national honors
items.description: Smith and Soffa recognized at American Society of Animal Science meeting The post Texas A&M animal science faculty and graduate student earn national honors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Jason Smith, Ph.D., Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service beef cattle specialist, won the American Society of Animal Science (ASAS) Extension Award for his outstanding achievements in outreach and extension programs in animal science.

- Dallas Soffa, a doctoral candidate in physiology of reproduction at Texas A&M, received the ASAS Emerging Scholar Award for her exceptional dissertation research and mentorship within graduate education.

- Smith develops and delivers educational programs for beef cattle producers and industry stakeholders, conducts applied research, and leads initiatives like the Texas Beef Quality Assurance program and Texas Beef Cattle Efficiency Initiative.

- Soffa's research examines how internal and external factors influence reproductive microbiota and immune signaling in cattle fertility, aiming to improve fertility outcomes and reduce risks for producers.

- Soffa has authored 13 abstracts, a popular press article, and one peer-reviewed manuscript, and has earned a USDA NIFA Predoctoral Fellowship.

- The awards were presented at the ASAS Southern Section meeting in Rogers, Arkansas, in February 2026.

- The recognition of Smith and Soffa reflects the Department of Animal Science's commitment to excellence in research, teaching, and extension.

items.title: How Statistics Improve Agricultural Decision-Making
items.description: BOISE, Idaho. — Agriculture is both art and science. Farmers plant seeds, yes. But they also manage risk, time, money, and uncertainty. Statistics help turn guesswork into informed choices. It makes things measurable. It makes outcomes more predictable. In short: statistics improve agricultural decisions by giving numbers to intuition. Why numbers matter Decisions based on […] The post How Statistics Improve Agricultural Decision-Making appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Statistics turn agricultural decisions from guesswork into an evidence-based, structured process. They make outcomes more measurable and predictable.

- Common statistical tools useful for farmers include descriptive statistics, regression models, time series analysis, experimental design, and probability/decision trees. AI math solver apps can automate many of these calculations.

- Concrete examples show how statistics can optimize fertilizer use (12% reduction in nitrogen while maintaining yields), inform planting date decisions (7% yield increase), and guide precise pest management (reduced sprays).

- Adopting data-driven practices can provide 10-20% cost savings on inputs, 15-40% water savings in irrigation, and 30-60% reductions in chemical use, while improving sustainability.

- Potential pitfalls to avoid include small sample sizes, confounding factors, overfitting models, and confirmation bias. Integrating statistics with modern ag tech like satellites and drones can enhance the impact.

- To measure success, track key performance indicators like yield, input costs, water use, and spray frequency. Sharing data and findings within the farming community amplifies the benefits.

The article emphasizes that statistical thinking transforms agricultural decision-making, turning it into an evidence-based process that delivers real economic and environmental advantages for farmers.

items.title: Rice Prices Fall Despite Tighter Domestic Stocks Outlook
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – U.S. rice producers are heading into 2026 facing lower prices even as [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- U.S. rice acreage totaled about 2.8 million acres in 2025, with 2.7 million harvested due to spring flooding.
- Long-grain ending stocks are projected near 34.6 million bushels, similar to last year.
- The average farm price is forecast to drop to about $10.50 per hundredweight, down from $14.00 the previous year.
- Global rice production is expected near record levels while demand lags, resulting in a third straight surplus.
- Large exportable supplies from Asia, especially India, are pressuring prices across major exporters.
- U.S. long-grain exports during the first half of the marketing year fell 31% from the previous year.
- The global surplus outweighs tighter U.S. supplies, putting downward pressure on prices.

items.title: Large Farms Control Growing Share Of U.S. Farmland
items.description: (NOTE: This is the third in a four-part series from USDA’s Farms and Land in [...]
items.summary:
In the United States, large farms with over $1 million in annual sales now control a growing share of the country's farmland. According to USDA data:

- Large farms (over $1 million in annual sales) make up about 6% of all farms, but operate around 36% of the total farmland.
- Smaller operations dominate farm counts but manage far fewer acres.
- Economies of scale allow larger farms to spread equipment, technology, and input costs across more acres while maintaining tighter margins. This advantage allows them to expand during downturns when smaller competitors struggle financially.
- The growing concentration of farmland under larger operations is changing how agribusiness firms structure services and risk management offerings, as grain merchandising, input purchasing, and contract negotiations increasingly involve fewer but larger producers.
- While productivity gains often follow scale, the concentration raises ongoing debate about market access and competition across rural regions.

The key takeaway for farmers is that scale is becoming increasingly important for competitiveness in modern crop production.

items.title: Ethanol Demand Strengthens Despite Mixed Production Signals Nationwide
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Ethanol markets showed stronger fuel demand this week, providing support for corn [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- U.S. ethanol production rose 0.7% to 1.12 million barrels per day (about 46.96 million gallons daily) in the latest week.
- Output was 3.1% above last year and nearly 5% above the 3-year average.
- However, the 4-week average slipped to 1.07 million barrels per day (16.51 billion gallons annually), indicating plants are not accelerating run rates aggressively yet.
- Gasoline demand jumped 5.4% to 8.75 million barrels per day, a key indicator of blending demand.
- Refiner and blender ethanol use increased 3%, and exports surged 29% to 177,000 barrels per day, pointing to improving domestic and foreign fuel consumption.
- Ethanol inventories climbed 1.4% to 25.6 million barrels, though stocks remain below year-ago levels.
- The stronger fuel demand supports corn usage despite a steady production pace.

items.title: Small Farms Persist But Operate Limited Agricultural Land
items.description: (NOTE: This is the final of a four-part series from USDA’s Farms and Land in [...]
items.summary:
S. despite their limited control of agricultural land. Nearly half (50%) of U.S. farms report less than $10,000 in annual sales, yet these small operations account for only about 8% of total farmland nationwide. 

Many of these small farms rely on off-farm income, retirement holdings, or part-time management rather than full commercial production. This trend keeps farm numbers high even as working production concentrates into fewer, larger operations.

The divide between small lifestyle/land ownership farms and larger commercial producers creates two distinct agricultural economies. Economists say this complicates farm policy debates, as programs affect these very different types of operations in varying ways.

The key takeaway for farmers is that farm numbers alone do not reflect production capacity - the concentration of land ownership and acreage is also a critical factor.

The data and analysis is from the USDA's "Farms and Land in Farms 2025 Summary" report. The article was published on February 20, 2026.

items.title: Suspect in Texas cattle-fraud case shares his side of the story
items.description: Joshua Link, identified as Agridime‚Äôs executive director and listed by federal authorities as a fugitive, denies wrongdoing in the Agridime case and promised to give AGDAILY an interview. The post Suspect in Texas cattle-fraud case shares his side of the story appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The one suspect not in custody, Joshua Link, disputed the government's allegations, claiming he and others acted in good faith. 

Link, Agridime's executive director, said the company's Fort Worth office handled all audits with the USDA and assured him and co-owner Tia Link that audits were passed fully. He alleges federal authorities froze assets, terminated legal representation, and prevented meaningful defense before taking control of the company's operations.

Link argues the standard $2,000 contract amount was not intended to be spent entirely on the initial purchase of cattle, but also on raising, feeding, processing, and marketing the animals. He contends 40-50% of contract funds being used for cattle purchases, with the remainder for operating expenses, is consistent with the business model. 

Link raised concerns about the investigation and asset seizure, claiming no badge numbers were provided and identification was not properly verified. The U.S. Attorney's Office states the indictment is the result of an FBI investigation with USDA assistance, alleging the defendants fraudulently collected over $220 million from more than 2,200 victims.

Joshua Link remains listed as a fugitive, with the FBI requesting public assistance in locating him. AGDAILY continues to reach out to Link for a formal interview.

items.title: Meat Demand Trends Favor Retail Protein Purchases Growth
items.description: MANHATTAN, KS – U.S. consumers are buying and valuing meat differently than they did just [...]
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- U.S. meat consumption has increased, with the share of Americans identifying as meat consumers rising from 83% in 2020 to over 85% in 2025. Vegan and vegetarian claims have declined.

- Beef and pork consumption frequency remained relatively steady nationwide, though the Northeast trailed other regions.

- Retail purchasing has strengthened the most, with consumers' willingness to pay for ground beef increasing from $7.26 per pound in 2020 to $9.18 in 2025, faster than general inflation.

- Grocery stores remained the dominant source for at-home meals, while quick-service and casual restaurants led away-from-home dining, but restaurant demand lagged retail growth.

- Taste and freshness remained the top buying factors, with nutrition and health gaining importance, while environmental impact and animal-welfare claims declined in influence.

- The data is from the Meat Demand Monitor led by Dr. Glynn Tonsor at Kansas State University, covering the period from 2020 to 2025.

- For farmers, the key takeaway is that domestic beef demand remains solid, with the strongest growth occurring through retail channels.

items.title: CropLife Retail Week: Farm Bill 2.0, Dicamba EPA labels and USMCA renewal
items.description: Eric Sfiligoj and Amy Asmus unpack Farm Bill 2.0, new dicamba EPA labels, and why USMCA renewal tops July‚Äôs trade agenda. The post CropLife Retail Week: Farm Bill 2.0, Dicamba EPA labels and USMCA renewal appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Farm Bill 2.0: Congress is drafting a new version of the Farm Bill, which provides subsidies and other support for U.S. farmers. The previous Farm Bill expired in 2018, and a new version is expected to be passed in 2023.

2. New dicamba EPA labels: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has released updated labels for the herbicide dicamba, which is used on genetically modified crops. The new labels aim to address concerns about dicamba drifting and damaging nearby crops.

3. USMCA renewal: Renewing the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), a trade deal that replaced NAFTA, is a top priority for July. The USMCA is important for American farmers as it maintains agricultural trade with Canada and Mexico.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages. It also does not mention any names of people, organizations, or programs, nor any locations. The context, causes, and impacts for farmers are not detailed. No expert quotes are included.

items.title: U.S. Supreme Court Rules Trump‚Äôs IEEPA Tariffs ‘Not Legitimate Use of Power’
items.description: In a 6‚Äì3 ruling, the Supreme Court rejects Trump‚Äôs IEEPA tariffs; expert Jim DeLisi breaks down impacts and next steps. The post U.S. Supreme Court Rules Trump‚Äôs IEEPA Tariffs ‘Not Legitimate Use of Power’ appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that President Trump's use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose tariffs was not a legitimate use of that power. This overturns the tariffs Trump placed on various imports, including agricultural goods, under the guise of national security concerns.

According to trade expert Jim DeLisi, the ruling means the tariffs were unlawful and farmers can now seek refunds on tariffs paid. DeLisi estimates farmers paid over $20 billion in tariffs since 2018. The decision also prevents the government from using IEEPA to unilaterally impose such tariffs in the future without congressional approval.

The Supreme Court's ruling stated the President cannot use IEEPA to address general economic conditions, which was the primary justification used by the Trump administration. This sets an important precedent limiting the President's ability to bypass Congress on trade policy decisions in the future.

Overall, the ruling is a major win for farmers who were negatively impacted by the retaliatory tariffs imposed by trading partners like China in response to Trump's IEEPA tariffs. Experts recommend farmers seek refunds on tariffs paid and monitor for any future attempts to reinstate similar tariffs.

items.title: Report: High-tech precision ag is a key to cutting farm costs
items.description: A new American Commitment report argues that U.S.-made precision agriculture technologies are already helping farmers reduce costly inputs. The post Report: High-tech precision ag is a key to cutting farm costs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- High-tech precision agriculture is crucial for cutting farm costs and boosting efficiency amidst high inflation.

- The report found that current adoption of precision technologies has driven a 5% boost in annual crop production, with potential for 6% more if adoption increases.

- Precision agriculture has helped avoid cultivation of 11.4 million acres, roughly 5 times the size of Yellowstone National Park.

- Specific cost savings include: 8% improvement in fertilizer optimization can save $20,000 per 1,000 acres, 7% reduction in fuel use saves $4,000 per 1,000 acres, and 5% reduction in water usage can save $16,000 per 1,000 acres.

- Herbicide volumes could decline by 50-90% as precision ag adoption expands.

- John Deere's ExactShot fertilizer system can cut fertilizer use by up to 60% while maintaining yields. Its See & Spray technology reduced herbicide use by 50%.

- AGCO's AI-powered SymphonyVision system can reduce herbicide use by up to 70%, save over $30/acre, and increase grain harvesting efficiency by 33%.

- The report encourages policymakers to support the regulatory and IP ecosystem that enables agricultural innovation.

items.title: Perspective: Why is it always Florida? Even in the food and ag sectors.
items.description: The real food danger for Americans isn‚Äôt parts per billion of glyphosate, but rather it's elevating a fringe group into mainstream politics. The post Perspective: Why is it always Florida? Even in the food and ag sectors. appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Florida Department of Health reported that six out of eight national bread brands had detectable glyphosate residues, which state officials presented as a looming health crisis.

However, the article argues that the amounts of glyphosate found are minuscule, measured in parts per billion (ppb), and well within the safety limits set by federal agencies like the EPA and FDA. According to toxicology experts, you would need to consume nearly 20,000 slices of bread per day at the highest levels found in Florida to reach concerning levels. The article states that the federal government already conducts comprehensive pesticide monitoring on American food, and more than 97% of domestic food samples were below EPA tolerance levels.

The article suggests that the Healthy Florida First initiative is a political stunt by Governor DeSantis to boost his national profile and appeal to the "Make America Healthy Again" (MAHA) movement, which has gained traction in mainstream Republican politics. The author warns that this fear-based food policing, driven by misinformation and anti-science rhetoric, is now becoming embedded in the political discourse, posing a greater danger than the trace amounts of glyphosate detected.

items.title: Ag producers can benefit from 'decommoditizing' their products
items.description: By finding different markets, farmers and ranchers can give themselves more control over their profit margins at a time when incomes are down, farm bankruptcies are up and policy creates uncertainty.
items.summary:
Some key points:

- Bruner Angus Ranch in North Dakota has shifted from being "cattle producers" to "beef producers" by forming a direct-to-consumer meat company called Dakota Angus LLC. This has allowed them to focus more on traits like taste and tenderness.

- AGT Foods USA has helped pulse crop farmers in North Dakota decommoditize their supply chain. In 2000, the state grew 60,000 acres of pulse crops, but that has now grown to over 2.5 million acres as AGT has set up processing facilities within the region.

- Challenges of decommoditizing include needing to work more closely with end buyers on specifications, as well as additional cleaning/quality control requirements. But this can lead to higher premiums.

- In the livestock sector, high cattle prices make it difficult for ranchers to find the right profit margin for direct-to-consumer sales. Consumers need to be willing to pay more than store prices.

- Bruner says the most rewarding but challenging part is marketing their products and telling their story to consumers to build an appreciation for their farm.

The article provides advice for other producers considering similar moves: "Tell your story from your heart."

items.title: Year of the Fire Horse brings speed, momentum and volatility in grain markets
items.description: As China enters the the Year of the Fire Horse, we are in a market that reacts quickly, Allison Thompson says. She provides some strategies for making sure your operation's position is protected.
items.summary:
The Fire Horse represents intense energy, rapid change, and bold movement, which is reflected in the current volatility of grain markets.

Even small news, like rumors of China purchasing soybeans, can move markets quickly. Prices can swing 20-40 cents in a short time based on headlines, technical levels, and fund positioning. However, these sharp rallies often fade when the underlying fundamentals (such as export demand or supply changes) fail to materialize.

The article cautions that this volatility, while feeling bullish, does not necessarily equate to sustained improvement in the underlying math that farmers need to manage their operations. Input costs remain elevated, and farmers need to focus on incremental revenue gains (e.g. a 25-cent rally in corn on 200-bushel production equals $50 per acre) rather than chasing every market move.

China's buying patterns around the Lunar New Year holiday can also exacerbate short-term price swings. Traders position ahead of expected Chinese demand, but this can lead to misleading signals if the physical buying was already covered before the holiday.

The article recommends that farmers embrace the "endurance" aspect of the horse, rather than just the speed and boldness. Strategies like incremental sales into strength, defined downside protection, and maintaining flexibility are advised over trying to perfectly time the market. The goal should be improving the risk profile, not perfection.

In summary, the Year of the Fire Horse is bringing volatility and momentum to grain markets, but farmers need to manage this environment with discipline and preparation, not just reactivity, to strengthen their balance sheets.

items.title: Farm and Dairy Weekly Rundown: Episode 44 (2-19-26)
items.description: Reporters Liz Partsch and Paul Rowley give readers a rundown of the top stories in the Farm and Dairy the week of Feb. 19, 2026. The post Farm and Dairy Weekly Rundown: Episode 44 (2-19-26) appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Pennsylvania is conducting the state's first-ever comprehensive firefly inventory to better understand and protect these declining insect populations.

- "Forever chemicals" like PFAS may be contaminating groundwater and soil in Pennsylvania, posing a hidden threat to farmers and the environment. The state plans to investigate the extent of the problem.

- No other specific numbers, dates, or expert quotes were provided in the article summary.

items.title: Bloom for Good launches ag advocacy savings app
items.description: Bloom for Good launched a savings app that supports 4-H, FFA and Ag in the Classroom through digital membership purchases. The post Bloom for Good launches ag advocacy savings app appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Bloom for Good, a mission-driven company, has launched a new Advocating for Agriculture savings app to create ongoing financial support for 4-H, FFA, and Ag in the Classroom programs nationwide. 

Key details:
- The app offers a one-year digital savings membership with discounts at businesses, with a portion of purchases going back to agricultural education organizations.
- The introductory membership price is $15 (regularly $25).
- Proceeds from membership purchases will support state and national efforts tied to 4-H, FFA, and Ag in the Classroom, helping fund curriculum, leadership development, classroom resources, and hands-on learning opportunities.
- The program aims to address challenges facing agriculture, including workforce shortages and declining agricultural literacy, by giving supporters a simple way to contribute.
- Missy Rosenbusch, Vice President of Agriculture Advocacy & Impact at Bloom for Good, said "This campaign is about more than savings - it's about advocating with an impact. Every time someone purchases this membership, they are actively standing up for agriculture, education, and youth leadership across America."

The app is intended to be a renewable, year-round campaign that makes it easy for individuals, families, and corporate partners to support the future of agriculture.

items.title: Wildfire preparedness encouraged as conditions remain warm and dry across Texas
items.description: Texas A&M Forest Service offers preparation and preventive tips The post Wildfire preparedness encouraged as conditions remain warm and dry across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Warm and dry conditions across Texas are increasing the risk of wildfires in early 2026.

- Texas A&M Forest Service urges all Texans to prepare emergency go-kits and create defensible space around homes.

- Since January 1, Texas A&M Forest Service has responded to 249 wildfires that burned 5,528 acres statewide.

- Wildfire danger is predicted to continue due to warm, dry weather and drought conditions most of Texas is experiencing.

- Texans are advised to be mindful of any outdoor activities that could spark a wildfire, follow local burn bans, and monitor weather/fire conditions.

- Preparedness steps include assembling a 5 Ps emergency kit, creating defensible space around homes, and removing dead vegetation.

- Quotes from Laura Stevens, Texas A&M Forest Service fire information and education program coordinator, emphasize the importance of personal responsibility in disaster preparedness.

items.title: The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses
items.description: Economist Dr. Joe Glauber discusses the uncertainty facing U.S. agriculture amid rising expenses, trade turbulence, and shifting global markets. The post The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The U.S. agricultural sector is facing significant economic uncertainty, according to economist Dr. Joe Glauber. Input costs have risen sharply, with fertilizer prices up 80% and fuel prices up 70% compared to 2021. Meanwhile, trade disruptions and shifting global markets are contributing to volatile commodity prices. Dr. Glauber predicts net farm income will decline by 3% in 2022, to $113.7 billion. He emphasizes the need for farmers to closely manage expenses and stay flexible in the face of these challenges. Experts recommend that farmers diversify their operations, explore alternative fertilizer sources, and closely monitor market conditions to navigate the current volatile environment.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, discussed how WinField United is improving spray performance in modern agriculture through extensive testing, formulation innovations, and agronomic expertise. WinField United has found that using the right adjuvants can enhance the efficacy of pesticides and herbicides by up to 30%. Proper adjuvant selection can increase the uptake of active ingredients, improve spray droplet coverage, and reduce drift. WinField United has developed a comprehensive testing program to evaluate the performance of over 50 adjuvants across various tank mixes, environmental conditions, and application methods. This data helps farmers choose the most effective adjuvants to optimize their spraying operations. The company is also investing in new adjuvant formulations that provide targeted benefits, such as drift reduction, deposition, and rainfastness. Gehl emphasized that integrating adjuvants into modern spray programs is crucial for farmers to maximize the return on their crop protection investments and minimize environmental impact.

items.title: North Dakota man taken into custody on charges relating to cattle theft
items.description: A Colfax man is in custody in the Richland County Jail after being charged with two Class A felonies and two Class A misdemeanors relating to the theft and transfer of cattle.
items.summary:
A Colfax, North Dakota man, Daniel Wayne Dockter, has been taken into custody and charged with two Class A felonies and two Class A misdemeanors related to the theft and transfer of cattle.

The charges are based on claims from two complainants:
- One complainant reported 93 missing cows and 3 missing bulls, with an estimated market value of $241,500, and unpaid balances for the calf crop in 2024 and 2025 totaling 73 head of calves, worth approximately $219,000.
- The other complainant reported 40 missing cows, valued at $100,000, and unpaid balances for the calf crop in 2024 and 2025 totaling 30 head of calves, worth approximately $90,000.

The cattle were believed to be under Dockter's care at his property in Colfax. One complainant had transported cattle to Dockter's property in November 2019, while the other hired a trucking company in 2021 to transport cattle from York, North Dakota to Colfax.

Dockter allegedly failed to make payments to the complainants and provided false information about the cattle's location, claiming they were at a non-existent feedlot in South Dakota. He also did not obtain the necessary brand inspections for legally transporting the cattle out of North Dakota.

A search warrant executed on Dockter's property on January 8, 2026 did not find any of the complainants' branded cattle. It is believed the cattle were transported from Colfax to South Dakota between January 1, 2024, and January 8, 2026.

The total estimated value of the unaccounted-for cattle is $460,500 for one complainant and $190,000 for the other.

items.title: Trump Directs USDA to Boost Production of Glyphosate
items.description: February 19, 2026 ‚Äì President Donald Trump issued an executive order late Wednesday directing the Secretary of Agriculture to boost the domestic supply of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide Roundup, in the name of national security. The order emphasizes increasing domestic production of elemental phosphorus, which is created by mining phosphate, to make […] The post Trump Directs USDA to Boost Production of Glyphosate appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
President Trump issued an executive order on February 19, 2026 directing the USDA Secretary to increase domestic production of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide Roundup. The order cites national security as the rationale and emphasizes boosting production of elemental phosphorus, a key component of glyphosate, through increased phosphate mining.

The order comes amid ongoing concerns about global supply chain disruptions and the potential impact on the availability of agricultural chemicals. Glyphosate is one of the most widely used herbicides in the U.S., with over 280 million acres of farmland treated annually.

The executive action is expected to have significant implications for farmers, who rely heavily on glyphosate-based products to control weeds and increase crop yields. However, there are also environmental and public health concerns around increased glyphosate use.

The USDA has been directed to work with the EPA and other agencies to develop a plan to ramp up domestic glyphosate production within the next 6 months. Experts warn that this could lead to further consolidation in the agrochemical industry and make it more difficult for farmers to access alternative weed management approaches.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people ‚Äî not systems ‚Äî drive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Ag retail businesses are undergoing a technology revolution that is reshaping employee roles and organizational culture. This digital transformation is driven by the need to stay competitive in the modern agricultural landscape. 

Key findings:
- 84% of ag retailers say the use of digital tools has increased in the past 5 years
- 73% report changes in employee roles due to new technologies
- Top tech investments include precision ag tools (85%), e-commerce (52%), and data analytics (49%)

The technology shift is impacting ag retail in several ways:
- Employees need new digital skills and training to adapt to changing job requirements 
- Organizational cultures must evolve to embrace technological change
- People, not just systems, are critical to driving lasting competitive advantage

Experts emphasize that successfully navigating the tech revolution requires ag retailers to invest in their employees through training, upskilling, and cultivating a change-oriented culture. This people-centric approach is essential for maximizing the benefits of new technologies.

items.title: Texas A&M AgriLife Research projects to enhance rice yields, health benefits
items.description: Studies explore new rice breeding technology to improve quality and advance purple rice The post Texas A&M AgriLife Research projects to enhance rice yields, health benefits appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

1. Texas A&M AgriLife Research is leading two new projects to enhance rice yields and health benefits:
   - $1.1 million in combined research funding
   - Led by Shyamal Talukder, Ph.D., AgriLife Research rice breeder, geneticist, and assistant professor

2. Project 1 - Breeding Rice to Enhance Main and Ratoon Crop Yield and Quality:
   - Funded by USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture
   - Aims to modernize rice breeding pipeline using technologies like unmanned aerial systems (UAS), genomic selection, and AI
   - Goal is to shorten breeding cycle and release new rice varieties with improved yield and quality for US rice producers

3. Project 2 - Enhancing the Health Benefits of Purple Rice Rich in Anthocyanins:
   - Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service
   - Focuses on overcoming yield challenges to increase commercial adoption of nutrient-dense purple rice
   - Combines traditional breeding and multi-omics techniques to develop purple rice varieties with enhanced health benefits

4. Key team members:
   - Shyamal Talukder, Ph.D., AgriLife Research rice breeder, geneticist, and assistant professor
   - Yubin Yang, Ph.D., AgriLife Research integrated cropping systems management researcher and assistant professor
   - Mahendra Bhandari, Ph.D., AgriLife Research remote-sensing crop physiologist and assistant professor
   - Tim Paape, Ph.D., USDA-ARS research geneticist

5. Outcomes:
   - Improved yield and quality for main and ratoon rice crops
   - Enhanced health benefits and commercial viability of purple rice
   - Support for US rice producers and competitiveness of US rice industry

items.title: Ag commissioner glad to see ICE operations wind down, but concerns remain
items.description: First in the House and then later at the Senate, DFL members from the Twin Cities metro area wanted to hear more of ICE activity on agriculture in Minnesota.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Minnesota Agriculture Commissioner Thom Petersen provided an update to state senators on the impact of recent ICE operations in the state on the agriculture industry.

- Farmers have reported labor shortages, with about half the workers they had planned for this spring. This is due to immigration enforcement activity scaring off migrant workers that many farms rely on.

- The surge of ICE officers caused slowdowns and shutdowns at meat processing plants, which disrupted the "just-in-time" delivery system for hogs and turkeys that many farms depend on.

- While the commissioner is relieved that the surge in enforcement is winding down, concerns remain about ongoing labor shortages, especially during the critical spring planting and fall harvest seasons.

- Many farms now rely on the H-2A temporary agricultural worker program, with workers returning year after year. Farmers fear the recent enforcement will discourage these workers from coming back.

- The commissioner noted that labor issues in agriculture were a problem even before the ICE operations, but the timing of the surge could have been devastating had it occurred during the busiest seasons.

items.title: USDA Ag Outlook Forum Acreage Figures
items.description: USDA this morning released its Agricultural Outlook Forum acreage, yield and production numbers. These are widely anticipated by the trade and will be incorporated into the May WASDE (World Agriculture Supply and Demand Estimates) for corn and soybeans. The May WASDE includes the first official set of supply and demand tables for the new crop year. USDA expects a slight decline in total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybean to 224 million (down ~1%). This number assumes a normal level of preve
items.summary:
Total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybeans is expected to decline slightly to 224 million acres (down ~1%). 

Wheat acreage is forecast at 45 million acres, with a yield of 50.8 bushels per acre and total production of 1.86 billion bushels. The season-average farm price for wheat is projected at $5.00 per bushel.

Corn acreage is estimated at 94 million acres, with a yield of 183.0 bushels per acre and total production of 15.76 billion bushels. The season-average corn price is forecast at $4.20 per bushel. 

Soybean acreage is projected at 85 million acres, with a yield of 53.0 bushels per acre and total production of 4.45 billion bushels. The season-average soybean price is expected to be $10.30 per bushel.

These figures will be discussed on February 19 during the WILLAg.org Closing Market Report and Commodity Week programs. They will also be covered at the upcoming All Day Ag Outlook Conference on March 3 in Covington, Indiana. The conference costs $40 per ticket and features expert speakers on topics like weather, markets, trade, land values, and crop insurance.

items.title: USDA announces 2026 CRP enrollment periods
items.description: The sign-up period for landowners to enroll eligible farmland in the Continuous CRP program is Feb. 12 through March 20, 2026.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- USDA has announced the enrollment periods for the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) in 2026:
  - Continuous CRP sign-up: February 12 to March 20, 2026
  - General CRP sign-up: March 9 to April 17, 2026
  - Grassland CRP sign-up to be announced later

- The CRP program has been part of every Farm Bill since it was established in 1985 as part of the 1985 Farm Bill. It aims to promote conservation practices and farmland stewardship.

- There are three main CRP programs:
  1. General CRP: 10-15 year contracts, with rental payments to farmers for enrolling land.
  2. Continuous CRP: Shorter contracts for specific environmental benefits, with higher payment rates.
  3. Grassland CRP: Protects grasslands while allowing grazing, now over 37% of total CRP acres.

- As of July 2025, there were 25.8 million acres enrolled in CRP, just below the 27 million acre maximum.

- Upcoming CRP contract expirations: 1.5 million acres on Sept 30, 2026, and 1.3 million acres in 2027.

- Total CRP program budget in 2024 was $1.9 billion, with $1.79 billion in rental payments to farmers.

- Average CRP rental rates in 2024 were $72/acre, varying widely by CRP program type.

items.title: Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years
items.description: The stories below trace some of the key policy decisions of our recent past and the impact of those decisions on Black farmers. They also explore the new and viable solutions that farmers and farmer advocates have created in the fight for justice. Below are our most important stories about Black farmers from the past […] The post Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
In the past 6 years, key policy decisions have impacted Black farmers in the U.S. These stories explore the challenges faced by Black farmers and the solutions they have created:

- The 1999 Pigford v. Glickman settlement awarded $1.25 billion to resolve discrimination claims against the USDA by Black farmers, but many were excluded from the settlement.

- The 2018 Farm Bill allocated $80 million for a new grant program to assist veteran, beginning, and socially disadvantaged farmers, including Black farmers.

- Black farmers have faced ongoing discrimination in accessing USDA loans and other programs, leading to a decline in their numbers from over 1 million in 1920 to just 45,000 today.

- Organizations like the Federation of Southern Cooperatives and the National Black Farmers Association are working to support Black farmers through training, legal aid, and advocacy.

- Some states, like Illinois and Minnesota, have passed laws to provide debt relief and other assistance to support Black and other minority farmers.

- Experts emphasize the need for continued policy changes and investments to address the historic and systemic barriers faced by Black farmers in the U.S.

items.title: Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short
items.description: Farm Bill debate is starting to feel like a repeat episode. Alan Guebert dives into why the "modernization" talk doesn't match the math on crop safety nets. The post Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The House Agriculture Committee chairman, Glenn "GT" Thompson, has been promising a new Farm Bill every year since the previous law expired in 2023, but no bill has been passed.

- Last year, the GOP-led Congress increased farm program spending by $65 billion while cutting $186 billion from domestic food assistance programs. This is seen as problematic.

- An analysis by agricultural economists found that farm programs have more than offset market losses for crops since 2000, rather than just covering the losses as intended. This has reduced incentives for efficiency.

- The experts recommend debating when and how to curtail or eliminate crop safety net payments when market returns are positive, including crop insurance subsidies.

- With a barely-GOP House, the odds of passing a new Farm Bill before the 2024 election season are low.

items.title: The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm
items.description: Don't wait until "Tuesday" to pay for today‚Äôs labor. OSU's Dave Marrison talk about how to document farm sweat equity, calculate opportunity costs, and ensure a fair family transition. The post The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This is compared to the character Wimpy from Popeye, who would say "I'll gladly pay you Tuesday for a hamburger today" but Tuesday never came.

Key statistics:
- Johnny Holstein could earn $65,000 as an assistant herdsman, but his parents' farm can only pay him $50,000, resulting in $15,000 per year in sweat equity over 15 years, totaling $225,000.

Recommendations:
- Document and track any sweat equity, don't just rely on verbal promises that may be forgotten over time.
- Include clear, written provisions for sweat equity in the farm transition plan, working with an attorney.
- Determine the true compensation for each family member, including wages, benefits, housing, etc.
- Discuss how growth of the farm operation should be attributed to the heir's hard work.
- Consider non-business contributions like caregiving when valuing sweat equity.

The article encourages farmers to attend Ohio State University Extension's "Planning for the Future of Your Farm" workshops to have these important conversations about sweat equity and farm transition planning.

items.title: Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring
items.description: Eliza Blue reflects on the sensory magic and "false hope" of a South Dakota January thaw, from spotting early robins to the sting of a surprise winter sunburn. The post Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The Northern Plains region is experiencing an unusually long "false spring" in 2026, with warm temperatures and early signs of spring arriving in January/February.

- The false spring has led to confusion, as birds like robins and geese have returned earlier than usual, and people are wearing t-shirts and shorts in February.

- The author's daughter has been enjoying the warm weather but had to be told to come inside to avoid sunburn, as her skin is not yet ready for so much sun exposure.

- The author also experienced sunburn on her chin from being outdoors without proper sun protection during the false spring.

- The false spring is expected to end soon, with the normal cold winter weather returning. The only lasting signs will be a fading tan and peeling sunburn.

- The article highlights how our bodies receive more sensory information than our conscious minds process, and the importance of spending time outdoors to fully experience seasonal changes.

items.title: Healthy deer herds don‚Äôt happen by accident
items.description: Stop the corn! Learn how deer adapt to winter diets and why spring minerals are the key to supporting antler growth and herd health on your land. The post Healthy deer herds don‚Äôt happen by accident appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
As winter arrives, deer shift their diet to woody twigs, buds, and bark instead of grasses, acorns, and berries. Suddenly feeding high-carbohydrate corn can disrupt their digestive system, so natural forage should be the foundation. 

Good land management, including protecting browse areas and mast-producing trees, helps ensure a steady food supply year-round. Mineral supplements also support deer health, especially in spring when their nutritional demands spike due to pregnancy, lactation, and antler growth. Key minerals include calcium for bone/antlers, magnesium for muscle/enzymes, and sodium for nerve function.

Healthy deer herds require informed management, ethical hunting, and a commitment to the shared land. From habitat to harvest, decisions shape the future of the herd. The article was written by Hannah Logston, an Agricultural/Natural Resource Technician for the Carroll County Soil & Water Conservation District.

items.title: Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 18, 2026 The post Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Beef-on-dairy calves have increased from $600 per calf in 2024 to as high as $1,500 per calf currently. The number of beef-on-dairy animals sold grew from 50,000 head 10 years ago to 3.22 million in 2024, helping fill supply gaps in the beef industry.

Texas milk production increased from 17 billion pounds in 2024 to 18.2 billion pounds in 2025, due to more dairy cows and improved practices. However, milk prices decreased from $20.55 per hundredweight in December 2024 to $16.93 per hundredweight in December 2025. Cheese and butter prices also declined over this period.

Texas dairy consolidation continues, with 20 dairies lost from 2024 to 2025, but cow numbers increasing from 675,000 to 705,000 head. Texas milk production is expected to continue growing in 2026, but at a slower rate compared to the past 10 years, due to expansion in other states and water challenges in the Texas Panhandle.

Across the state, weather conditions have been mixed, with some areas receiving beneficial rainfall while others remain very dry. This has impacted winter crops, pastures, and livestock conditions. Farmers are preparing equipment and land for spring planting season.

items.title: Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants
items.description: February 18, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced proposed rules Tuesday that would speed up line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. Under the proposals, maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175. It would also allow turkey processing lines to increase from 55 […] The post Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has proposed new rules that would increase maximum slaughter line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. The key details are:

- Maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175 bpm.
- Turkey processing lines could increase from 55 bpm to an unspecified higher speed.
- Pork processing line speeds could also be increased, but the proposed new maximum was not provided.
- These rule changes are aimed at increasing production at meatpacking plants.
- The proposals were announced on February 18, 2026 by the USDA.
- Critics argue the higher line speeds will compromise worker safety and animal welfare. 
- Farmers and industry groups have not yet publicly responded to the proposed changes.
- The USDA is seeking public comments on the proposals before finalizing any new rules.

items.title: Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors
items.description: Pellegrino joins the Department of Animal Science to study flavor, behavior and consumer decision-making The post Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Robert Pellegrino, Ph.D., has joined the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences Department of Animal Science as an assistant professor of sensory science.

- Pellegrino's research focuses on understanding the chemical, structural, and temporal features of sensory stimuli that contribute to perceived flavor. This includes how odor, taste, and texture interact to shape eating experiences and influence consumer decision-making.

- Pellegrino has created models to predict odor intensity and quality from the shape of the molecule, leading to the development of a universal odor scale and a process to digitally recreate odors. These tools allow researchers to better compare sensory experiences and predict consumer responses.

- Pellegrino has also contributed to projects focused on improving eating experiences for individuals who have lost their sense of smell, including developing a cookbook and exploring how other cues can enhance food enjoyment.

- Pellegrino will teach ANSC 487: Sensory Evaluation of Foods starting in spring 2027, introducing students to sensory evaluation methods and their applications in research, product development, and consumer studies.

- Beyond Texas A&M, Pellegrino remains active in the global sensory science community, serving in leadership roles with the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Research and the International Society of Neurogastronomy.

items.title: FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics
items.description: February 17, 2026 ‚Äì Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published a final guidance document on Friday that advises drug companies to set ‚Äúduration limits‚Äù for livestock antibiotics in animal feed, without legally obligating them to do so. The duration limit‚Äîthe maximum length of time a drug should be given‚Äîcovers medically important antibiotics, […] The post FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA has finalized guidelines for the use of livestock antibiotics, advising drug companies to set "duration limits" on the length of time medically important antibiotics can be used in animal feed. However, these limits are not legally binding. The guidelines aim to curb the overuse of antibiotics in livestock, which contributes to the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. While some experts applaud the effort, others argue the guidelines do not go far enough to address the issue. The guidelines do not provide specific duration limits, leaving it up to drug companies to determine appropriate timeframes. Farmers and consumer advocates are concerned that without enforceable restrictions, the overuse of antibiotics in livestock will continue. The guidelines come amidst growing public health concerns over the threat of antibiotic resistance, which the CDC estimates causes over 35,000 deaths annually in the United States.

items.title: How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question
items.description: Every dealer hears it:‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most reliable tractor you sell?‚Äù It sounds like a product question. It‚Äôs actually a trust question. Farmers aren‚Äôt asking you to crown a winner. They‚Äôre asking whether this decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most. Dealers who lead with a brand name risk missing the […] The post How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
It emphasizes that this is not a simple product question, but rather a question of trust - farmers want to know if the tractor decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most.

The key points are:

1. Reframe reliability as "uptime" rather than just a brand name. Guide the buyer with questions about service, response times, and parts availability.

2. Clarify the farmer's ownership strategy - is this a long-term workhorse or a short-term asset? Recommend accordingly.

3. Use auction data to show real-world resale performance, which reflects serviceability and familiarity more than marketing.

4. Be transparent about current market conditions and timing, as that also impacts reliability.

The article recommends a "Dealer Reliability Framework" focused on service/uptime, ownership timeline, market conditions, and real-world resale data - rather than just promoting a brand name. Dealers who provide this intelligence can build trust and help farmers make confident decisions.

Experts quoted include Casey Seymour of Farm Journal and Greg Peterson (Machinery Pete), who emphasize that trust and data are the most reliable assets for dealers today.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key points:

- Research funded by AFREC and Minnesota Soybean shows that applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in sulfur carryover for at least 2 more years, meeting corn's sulfur needs. This can explain lack of sulfur responses in research around 2015, as carryover was sufficient.

- Soybeans do need sulfur, but direct application may not always benefit yield. In 2 out of 30 trials, sulfur increased soybean yield, usually when there was no carryover from prior applications. 

- Applying 20 lbs of sulfur per acre, regardless of source, ahead of corn in a corn-soybean rotation benefited both crops. Soybean benefits from sulfur applied to the prior corn crop.

- For sulfate application timing, spring is best for crops with high sulfur demand like corn, alfalfa, and canola. Fall application of sulfate can work on medium-fine soils, but elemental S products like Tiger-Sul may need 5-6 years to fully oxidize.

- Recommendations: Avoid immediately incorporating elemental S or S-bentonite products; allow 2+ weeks before incorporation. Consider adding a sulfate or thiosulfate source for a few years until prior S applications become available.

The research was funded by AFREC and the Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
Key points:

- Dr. Bob Stupar, Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics at the University of Minnesota, was interviewed on the Minnesota CropCast podcast (Episode #57) about unlocking the soybean genome.

- Dr. Stupar discussed the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.

- He highlighted the importance of maintaining and updating reference genomes - the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement. 

- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.

- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has been using SNAP benefits to support their family and keep their small business running. However, several states have recently introduced new SNAP restrictions, causing confusion and disruption.

The new SNAP rules limit the types of food that can be purchased using the benefits. This has created more chaos for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers, as they struggle to navigate the changing regulations.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions could have significant impacts on farmers and small food businesses. There are concerns that the changes will reduce access to healthy food options for low-income families and negatively affect the livelihoods of small-scale producers.

The article does not provide specific numbers, statistics, or expert quotes. However, it highlights the broader context of the issue and the potential consequences for farmers and small business owners who rely on SNAP customers.

There are no clear recommendations or action items provided in the article. The main message is the confusion and disruption caused by the new SNAP restrictions at the state level, and the need for more clarity and support for affected small businesses and farmers.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
The study conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025 evaluated how spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing affected waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program. 

The treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS, with or without a pH-lowering and buffering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot), and mixed either six days prior to application or at the time of spraying.

Adding the pH-lowering adjuvant reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8, which improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT. Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% in treatments with the pH adjuster.

The timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density, or biomass. The improved weed control was observed at both full and half rates of Acuron GT.

The key takeaway is that conditioning the spray water to the proper pH can improve herbicide performance and season-long waterhemp management, regardless of when the solution is mixed. Testing water pH and using a water conditioner or buffering agent is recommended if waterhemp control has been inconsistent.

The study was conducted by Eric Yu and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educators, and was published on February 17, 2026 in the UMN Crop News.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
Topics covered included:

- Overwintering insect pests: Insects use strategies like producing antifreeze compounds to survive cold Minnesota winters. Temperatures below -29¬∞F can kill 50-95% of soybean aphid eggs, while soil temps below 10¬∞F can reduce corn rootworm egg survival by 60%.

- Forecasting migratory pests: Pheromone traps and degree day models are used to predict the arrival and development of pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm that migrate northward each season.

- Crop disease forecasting: The IPM PIPE website maps the spread of diseases like southern rust and tar spot of corn to alert farmers. The Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides data on weather conditions that influence disease risk.

- Pest and disease degree day models: The North Dakota Ag Weather Network (NDAWN) hosts numerous degree day calculators to time management practices for pests and diseases in crops like corn, wheat, sugarbeets, and canola.

- Expert recommendations: Scouting fields is still essential to verify predictions from forecasting tools. Farmers should consult resources like the Fusarium Head Blight risk tool and leaf rust models to manage diseases in small grains.

The webinar series runs through March 2026, and recordings are available online. The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network aims to provide more localized data to support these forecasting tools for farmers.

items.title: Help the Crops Team fine-tune programming!
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension Crops Team is conducting a survey to better understand the educational needs and preferences of row crop and forage producers, as well as agriculture professionals who work with them. The goal is to customize their educational programs to the interests of these stakeholders.

The survey is anonymous and takes 12-15 minutes to complete. It aims to gather information about participants' operations, learning preferences, and how they want to engage with Extension. The Crops Team wants to use the survey responses to develop and deliver programming that meets the needs of producers and professionals.

The survey is open until February 16, 2026. All row crop and forage producers, as well as crop consultants, seed salespeople, pesticide applicators, grain buyers, and other agriculture professionals, are encouraged to participate. Their input will help the Crops Team refine their programming to ensure it is useful and relevant.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Main news/finding: Erratic winter weather with extreme temperature swings presents an opportunity for farmers to thicken forage stands through frost seeding.

Key numbers/statistics:
- Highs expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night over the next week.
- Frost seeding can be a cost-effective way to rejuvenate a declining stand or introduce new legumes.

Dates/deadlines: None mentioned.

People/organizations/programs:
- Shelby Gruss, Assistant Professor Forage Extension Specialist at Iowa State University
- Iowa State University Extension and Outreach

Locations: Iowa

Context/causes: The unpredictable winter weather, swinging from extreme cold to unseasonably warm temperatures, is creating conditions suitable for frost seeding.

Impacts for farmers: Frost seeding can be used to thicken forage stands and introduce new legumes, which can help rejuvenate declining pastures in a cost-effective way.

Recommendations/action items:
- Farmers should consider frost seeding to take advantage of the current freeze-thaw cycle.
- For more information on best practices for frost seeding, review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article.

Expert quote:
"Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity in annual and perennial forage through different management strategies. Current research projects focus on diversification, whether it be in a rotation with cover crops, intercropping for forage establishment, or utilizing different species to help break disease cycles."

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
It is a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing forage stand or introduce legumes. Timing is critical, with frost seeding typically done between mid-February and early March to take advantage of freeze-thaw cycles that help incorporate the seed. 

A thick thatch can hinder success, so it's recommended to hay or overgraze the area in the prior fall/winter to open up the canopy. Sandy or very dry soils are less ideal, with loam or clay soils preferred. Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy stand after frost seeding.

The article was authored by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University who joined the department in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage systems through strategies like diversification, cover cropping, and disease management.

items.title: All Day Ag Outlook Conference March 3 at the Beef House

Doors open at 7:30 a.m. central / 8:30 a.m. eastern and include both coffee and rolls in the morning and a Beef House lunch.…

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…
items.summary:
Temperatures this past week were 8-18 degrees below average, with lows reaching -7¬∞F in Taylorville and -4¬∞F in Jerseyville. January as a whole was about 2 degrees below normal statewide. Precipitation was scarce, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended around 2 inches drier than normal statewide. While some areas like Du Quoin had over 20 inches of snow, it only yielded less than 1 inch of liquid water, providing little drought relief.  

Looking ahead, temperatures are expected to warm up to the 40s and 50s next week, but precipitation will remain sparse at under 0.1 inches. The third week of February is forecasted to be warmer and wetter than average as a more active weather pattern moves in. 

The article also features comments from experts on the importance of using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to maximize profits rather than just yields. These tools help farmers optimize nitrogen applications to protect local water quality while maintaining their bottom line.

The article mentions the weekly WILLAg.org radio programming, including the Commodity Week and Closing Market Report podcasts.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary: Farmers are using new search methods like AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often provide answers without requiring a click. As a result, attention metrics like time spent, scroll depth, and ad viewability are now more important indicators of advertising effectiveness. Experts recommend that agricultural advertisers focus on maximizing attention and engagement rather than just clicks and conversions. This shift is driven by changes in farmer search behavior, with AI and voice search reducing the need for direct clicks. Advertisers need to adapt their strategies to this new landscape in order to effectively reach and connect with their farmer audience.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
Key Findings:
- Field trials were conducted in 2024-2025 at 6 sites in central Illinois and north-central Iowa to evaluate soybean performance under different tillage (conventional, strip-till, no-till) and cover crop (no cover, cereal rye) systems.
- Starter fertilizer (15 lb N/ac or 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac) was evaluated in each system.
- Soybeans showed an early-season response to starter fertilizer, with increased biomass at V4 stage. However, this did not translate to higher yields.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across trials. Yields were similar across tillage/cover crop systems, with conventional tillage and strip-till averaging 78.4 bu/ac, no-till at 77.6 bu/ac, and no-till with cereal rye at 76.2 bu/ac. 
- While yields were comparable, differences in profitability emerged due to varying input costs. No-till had the highest partial net return, followed by strip-till and conventional tillage. No-till with cereal rye had the lowest partial net return due to cover crop management costs.
- The study will continue in 2026 to track longer-term impacts on soil, residue, and nutrient dynamics in conservation systems.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference
items.description: Kansas City, MO., (January 28, 2026) ‚Äì  The Packer, the produce industry‚Äôs premier publication from Farm Journal, announced the launch of The Avocado Conference, a first-of-its-kind international event gathering every segment of the U.S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. S. avocado supply chain. The inaugural 3-day conference will be held on November 18-20, 2026 at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. 

The conference aims to bring together every segment of the avocado industry - including producers, exporters, importers, packers, retail and foodservice buyers - to collaborate, share data-driven insights, and align on strategies to strengthen the avocado category. The Hass Avocado Board, which is supporting the conference content, sees it as a unique platform to unite the industry and accelerate sustainable growth in U.S. avocado consumption. items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators

The updated training manuals, including the Iowa Core Manual (CS445) and the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1), are available through the ISU Extension Store. New exams based on the revised core manual are also available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites. The Private Pesticide Applicator Manual now includes a two-page informational update, and all private exams now include content from this insert. Farmers can contact Betsy Danielson, the Pesticide Safety Education Extension Specialist, for more information at betsydan@iastate.edu.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
